resource.chars:
4.840
On the Secular Variation of the Moon’s
Mean Motion. by <s>Mr.<\s> J.C. Adams Esqre. M.A., F.R.S. &c
recd. June 16 1859 J.B.
read same day.
In treating a great problem of approximation,
such as that presented to us by the investigation 
of the Moon’s motion, experience shows that 
nothing is more easy than to neglect, on account 
of their apparent insignificance, considerations 
which ultimately prove to be of the greatest 
importance. One instance of this occurs with reference 
to the secular acceleration, & the diminution of the 
eccentricity of the Earth’s orbit, on which it depends,
had been made known by observation, as separate 
facts, yet many of the first Geometers altogether 
failed to trace any connexion between them, and it 
was not till he had made repeated attempts to 
explain the phenomenon by other means, that 
Laplace himself succeeded in referring it to its 
true cause.
